TWENTIETH SESSION - 1956.PROPOSED ACTION ON THE DRAFT CONVENTION CONCERNING THE REGULATIONOF CERTAIN SPECIAL SYSTEMS OF RECRUITING WORKERS THE RECOMMENDATIONCONCERNING THE PROGRESSIVE ELIMINATION OF RECRUITING.Memorandum by the Secretary of State for the Colonies and the Minister of Labour. As our colleagues are aware, there have been several enquiries inParliament during the last two years as to the intentions of His Majesty'sGovernment in the United Kingdom in regard to the ratification of theDraft Convention concerning the Regulation of Certain Special Systems of recruiting Workers, which was adopted at the Twentieth Session of theInternational Labour Conference in June, 1956, and it was intimated in a paper (Cmd.5745) dealing with a number of Conventions and recommendations adopted by the International Labour Conference, which was presented toParliament by the Minister of Labour in May last, that His Majesty'sGovernment, proposed to ratify this particular Convention shortly when a few Ipoints of detail had been settled, and to append a declaration regardingits application to the non-self-governing dependencies in accordance withthe provisions of Article 25 of the. Convention.(See cabinet conclusions 22(58) 15), The text of the Convention has already been presented to Parliament in Cmd.5505.2, As in the case of the Forced Labour Convention, this Convention wasdrafted with a view primarily to the conditions prevailing in colonial dependencies. In regard therefore to this particular Convention, the -obligations of His Majesty's Government under Article 421 of the Treaty ofVersailles are of special importance." That Article provides that:- v "1. The Members engage to apply conventions which they have ratified in accordance with the provisions of this Part of the present Treaty to their colonies, protectorates and possessions which are not fully self-governing: (l) Except where pwing to the local conditions the convention is inapplicable, or (2) Subject to such modifications as may be necessary to adapt the convention to local conditions."" 1.. 'SECRET.C.P.255(38). In view also of the special character of this Convention, provision was ma.de in it (Article 25) that any Member of the International LabourOrganisation which ratified it should append to its ratification adeclaration stating: "(a) the territories to which it undertakes to' apply the provisions of the Convention without modification; .. (b) the territories to which it undertakes to apply the -provisions of the Convention subject to modifications, together with details of the said modifications; (c) the territories to which the Convention is inapplicable and in such cases the grounds on which it is inapplicable; (d) the territories in respect of which it reserves its decision."5. The framers of the Convention of course had primarily in mind conditionsobtaining in Africa and the Far East, and if we had ratified theConvention with a reservation in respect of any important African orFar Eastern Dependency, our .action would undoubtedly have been open to considerable criticism. The position in regard to certain of theEast African Dependencies, notably Nyasaland and Northern Rhodesia, fromwhich considerable numbers of indigenous workers have proceeded to theUnion of South Africa to work in the mines, presented some difficulty becausethe Government of the Union of South Africa raised objection to theprovisions of Article 20(l) of the Convention, which provides that theexpenses of the journey of recruited workers to the place of employmentshall be borne by the recruiter or employer. When this Article of theDraft Convention came up for discussion at the Plenary Session of theInternational Labour Conference in 1936, the representative of theUnion of South Africa explained that this provision was contrary to thepractice which had obtained in his country for many years and urged that itshould be qualified by a proviso that where the requirement was not inaccordance with local custom it might bo waived by the competent authorityif the authority was satisfied that in fixing wage rates the employers hadtmade reasonable allowance for the expenses of the workers in connectionwith their journey. The p:proposal of the representative of theUnion of South Africa was however rejected by the Conference, whichadopted the Article in its present form. It is understood that in viev/ ofthis decision the Government of the Union of South Africa decided not to ratify the Convention. In the meantime negotiations have taken place between tho Governors ofNorthern Rhodesia and Nyasaland and the Transvaal Chamber of Mines, as aresult of which the Chamber of Mines has agreed to meet the cost of transporting recruited labourers from Nyasaland to the Rand. No natives ofNorthern Rhodesia are at the present time being actually recruited in theterritory for work on the Rand, but in the event of such recruitment beingcontemplated at some future date, it is confidently anticipated that the transvaal Chamber of Mines would be similarly prepared to defray the cost oftransport from the territory, . It is therefore considered that Nyasaland andNorthern Rhodesia can be included in the territories to which the Conventionmay be applied without modification.4. After consideration of the replies received from the various colonial governors, it is proposed that the declaration to be appended to the ratification by His Majesty's Government shoiild. contain the following information: - (a) That the territories to which the Convention will be applied without modification are the following:- British Guiana, British Honduras, British Solomon Islands Protectorate, Ceylon, Fiji, Gambia, Gilbert and Ellice Islands Colony, Gold Coast, Hong Kong, Jamaica, Kenya, the Leeward Islands, the Malay States (Federated and Unfederated), Mauritius, Nigeria, North Borneo, Northern Rhodesia, Nyasaland, Sarawak, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somaliland Protectorate, Straits Settlements, Tanganyika Territory, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Uganda Protectorate and the Windward Islands (Grenada, St. Lucia and St. Vincent). (b) That the territories to which the Convention is inapplicable are:- Aden, Bermuda, Cyprus, Falkland Islands, gibraltar, Malta, Palestine, St. Helena, Trans-Jordan and Zanzibar. In the case of all these territories the reason is that no recruiting of the nature defined in the Convention exists or is likely to exist hereafter. In the case of Zanzibar, the,only recruiting of workers which exists takes the form of the engagement of indigenous workers from one part of the territory for service in another at the time of the clove harvest. These workers offer their services spontaneously and their engagement is arranged at offices under the supervision of the local authorities. 3. /jlliis practice therefore does not constitute recruiting within the meaning of the Convention in which the term is defined as follows:- "The term 1 recruiting' includes all operations undertaken with the object of obtaining; or supplying the labour of persons who do not spontaneously offer their services at the place of employment or at a public emigration or employment office or at an office conducted by an employers' organisation and supervised by the competent authority"^7 (c) That the territories in respect of which His Majesty's Government reserve their decision are:- Bahamas and Barbadoes, and also (for the reasons explained below) Basutoland, the Bechuanaland Protectorate and Swaziland. With regard to the Bahamas and Barbadoes, the reason for the proposed reservation is that, owing to their constitutional position, the Secretary of State for the Colonies is not in a position to direct that any specific legislation shall be enacted. The Governors of these two Dependencies have been urged to introduce the legislation necessary to give effect to the provisions of the Convention, but some doubt exists at the moment whether the local Legislatures will consent to its enactment, particularly in view of the fact that recruiting of "che nature defined in the Convention is non-existent or negligible at the present time. With regard to Basutoland, the Bechuanaland Protectorate and Swaziland (which falls within the sphere of the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs), we are informed that considerable recruiting takes place in these territories for the Rand, and that the High Commissioner for the Territories originally advised that it would be necessary, in applying the Convention to them, to adopt the modification that Article 20(1) should be read in their case with the proviso originally proposed to meet the position in the Union of South Africa, namely, that where the requirement specified in that Article was not in accordance with local custom, it may be waived by the competent authority, if thev authority is satisfied that the employers, in fixing wage rates, have made reasonable allowance for the expenses of the workers in connection with their journeys. Since then, confidential information has been received that the Transvaal Chamber of Mines are proposing shortly to arrange to pay the expenses of rail transport of recruited natives from the Territories to the Rand. It is not, however, at present altogether clear whether this concession will "be sufficient to enable the Convention to be applied to the Territories without modification, since there is no railway in Swaziland and only one mile of railway in Basutoland. This point is at present under consideration by the Secretary of State for V Dominion Affairs in consultation with the High Commissioner. In the meantime the Territories have been provisionally included in the list of those in respect of which it is desired to reserve a decision, though it may be possible before the actual ratification of the Convention to determine whether or not a modification on the above lines will be necessary.5, We therefore suggest that we be authorised to apply for the necessary order of Council and to communicate the ratification of the Convention to theSecretary-General of the League of Nations accompanied by a declaration on thelines indicated above.6. The International Labour Conference at its Twentieth Session also adopted a Recommendation concerning the Progressive Elimination of Recruiting, the text of which vra.s presented to Parliament in Cmd.5305. The Recommendation advocates that each Member of the InternationalLabour Organisation should take steps to hasten such elimination by (a) improvement of the conditions of labour; (b) development of the means of transport; (c) promotion of the settlement of workers and their families in the area of employment, where such settlement is the policy of the competent authority; (d) facilitating the voluntary movement of labour under administrative supervision and control; and (e) the educational development of indigenous peoples and the improvement of their standard of living. It is considered that the policy advocated in paragraphs (c) and (d) ofthe Recommendation is contrary to the policy which it may be found desirableto adopt in certain of the African Dependencies, where an excess of voluntarymovement of labour has led to serious social problems and where it is desiredto encourage the native worker to return to his tribe on the expiry of hiscontract of employment. It is therefore suggested that the communication to (Intd.) M.M.(Intd.) E.B.Colonial Office,Ministry^of Labour.11th November, 1938.be made to the Secretary-G-eneral of the League of Nations should state thatHis Majesty's Government propose to accept the Recommendation, subject to the reservation that the steps envisaged in sub-clauses (c) and (d) cannot beaccepted as suitable for application in certain African dependencies. If our proposals are accepted His Majesty's Government's intentions wouldbe communicated to Parliament as usual by means of a Command Paper, the draftof which is annexed. The decision of His Majesty's Government to ratify this draft Convention when a few points of detail had "been settled and to append a declaration regarding its application to the non self-governing dependencies was communicated to Parliament in Cmd. 5745. His Majesty's Government now propose to ratify the draft Convention and, in accordance with Article 25 of the draft Convention, to append to the instrument of ratification a declaration regarding its application in the terms set out in the Annex hereto. Recommendation concerning the Progressive Elimination of Recruiting. The Recommendation advocates that each Member of the InternationalLabour Organisation should take steps to hasten such elimination by (a) improvement of the conditions of labour; (b) development of the means of transport; (c) promotion of the settlement of workers and their families in the area . of employment, where such settlement is the policy of the competent authority 5 (d) facilitating the voluntary movement of labour under admini strative supervision and control; and (e) the educational development of indigenous peoples and the improvement of their standard of living. His Majesty's Government consider that the policy advocated inparagraphs (c) and (d) of the Recommendation is contrary to the policy which itmay be found desirable to adopt in certain of the African Dependencies, where an excess of voluntary movement of labour has led to serious social problems and where it is desired to encourage the native worker to return to his tribeon the expiry of his contract of employment. It is therefore proposed toinform the Secretary General of the League of Nations that His Majesty'sGovernment accept the Recommendation subject to the reservation that thes*steps envisaged in sub-clauses (c) and (d) cannot be accepted as suitable for application in certain African Dependencies. This Convention was adopted by the International LabourConference at its twelfth session in 1929 and the French and english texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 3441. H.M. Government are in sympathy with the objects of theConvention but there are technical difficulties with regard tointerpretation which are being investigated by the InternationalLabour Office. Meanwhile, H.M. Government propose to take no decision with regard to ratification.Recommendation concerning Unemployment among Young Persons. This Recommendation was adopted by the InternationalLabour Conference at its nineteenth session in 1935 and theFrench and English texts were presented to Parliament in cmd. 5033. The Recommendation is to the effect that each Member state should apply certain principles and should submit to the Inter-national Labour Office a report showing the extent to which theyare applied. H.M. Government propose to submit a reportaccordingly.Convention limiting Hours of Work in Coal Mines [revised 1935)- This Convention was adopted by the International LabourConference at its nineteenth session in 1935 and the French and english texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5033. The revision of the Convention removed certain difficulties inan earlier Convention on the same subject adopted in 1931.H.M. Government are prepared to ratify the Convention simul-taneously with the other six principal coal producing countriesnamed in the Convention, viz., Belgium, Czechoslovakia,France, Germany, Netherlands and Poland. A TripartiteTechnical Meeting to consider the reduction of hours of workin coal mines, account being taken of the economic and socialfactors which might have a bearing on hours of work in that industry opened in Geneva on 2nd May, 1938. Convention concerning the Reduction of Hours of Work to Forty . a Week. This Convention was adopted by the International Labour Conference at its nineteenth session in 1935 and the French and English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5033. Members which ratify this Convention declare their approval of the principle of a forty hour week applied in such a manner that the standard of living is not reduced in consequence and undertake to apply this principle to classes of employment in accordance with any subsequent Conventions they may ratify. For the reasons indicated in the replies of H.M. Government to the questionnaires on the subject of the reduction of hours of work in certain industries in connection with the Twentieth Session of the International Labour Conference in June, 1936 (Cmd. 5113) H.M. Government do not propose to ratify this convention. The question of the generalisation of the reduction of hours of work has been placed on the Agenda of the Twenty-fourth Session of the International Labour Conference to be held in June, 1938. Convention concerning the Reduction of Hours of Work in Glass- Bottle Works. This Convention was adopted by the International Labour Conference at its nineteenth session in 1935 and the French and English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5033. This Convention was adopted in confirmation of the principle laid down in the Convention concerning the Reduction of Hours of Work to Forty a Week and for the reasons referred to above in connection with that Convention H.M. Government do not propose to ratify it. Convention concerning the Reduction of Hours of Work on Public Works. This Convention was adopted by the International Labour Conference at its twentieth session in 1936 and the French and English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5305. For the reasons referred to above in connection with the Con-I vention regarding the Reduction of Hours of Work to Forty aI Week and for the additional reason that public works undertakenI or subsidised by Governments do not constitute a separatei class of employment but are a cross section of many such classes, H.M. Government do not propose to ratify this Con-I vention. i/Convention^ concerning the Regulation ' of Certain Special Systems of Recruiting Workers. Recommendation concerning the Progressive Elimination of Recruiting. This Convention and Recommendation were adopted by the International Labour Conference at its twentieth session in 1936 and the French and English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5305. H.M. Government propose to ratify this Convention shortly when a few points of detail have been settled and to append a declaration regarding its application to the non self-governing dependencies. H.M. Government propose to accept the recom- mendation with certain reservations with regard to African dependencies. Convention concerning Annual Holidays with Pay. Recommendation concerning Annual Holidays with Pay. This Convention and Recommendation were adopted by the International Labour Conference at its twentieth session in 1936 and the French and English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5305. A Committee of Enquiry has recently considered the question of holidays with pay in this country. The Committee reported on the 6th April, 1938, and the report is under consideration; meanwhile it is not possible to reach a decision as to the ratifica- tion of the Convention or the acceptance of the Recommendation. Part II.Recommendation concerning the Promotion of Seamen's Welfare in Ports. This Recommendation was adopted at the twenty-first sessionof the International Labour Conference in 1936 and the Frenchand English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5392. H.M. Government propose to accept this Recommendation.Convention concerning Minimum Requirement of Professional Capacity for Masters and Officers on board Merchant Ships. This Convention was adopted at the twenty-first session of theInternational Labour Conference in 1936 and the French and english texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5392. H.M. Government do not propose to ratify this Convention,as that would involve legislation which, in their opinion, would serve no useful purpose. Convention concerning Annual Holidays with Pay for Seamen. This Convention was adopted at the twenty-first session of theInternational Labour Conference in 1936 and the French and english texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5392. For the reasons set out above in connection with the Conven-tion concerning Annual Holidays with Pay, H.M. Governmentare not at present in a position to make a proposal with regardto the ratification of this Convention.Convention concerning the Liability of the Shipowner in Case of Sickness, Injury or Death of Seamen. This Convention was adopted by the International LabourConference at its twenty-first session in 1936 and the Frenchand English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5392. In the opinion of H.M. Government the system at present inforce in this country is more advantageous to seamen than that provided for by the Convention, and, consequently, they donot propose to ratify it.Convention concerning Sickness Insurance for Seamen. This Convention was adopted by the International LabourConference at its twenty-first session in 1936 and the Frenchand English texts were "presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5392. H.M. Government, propose to ratify this Convention.Convention concerning Hours of Work on board Ship and Manning. Recommendation concerning Hours of Work on board ship and Manning. This Convention and Recommendationwere adopted by the International Labour Conference at itstwenty-first session in 1936 and the French and English textswere presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5392. H.M. Government do not propose to ratify this Convention,as it would entail a variation of voluntary agreements recently made by the industry itself and also entail the laying down of maximum working hours for ships' officers, who occupy highlyresponsible positions, or to accept the Recommendation con-nected therewith.Convention fixing the Minimum Age for the Admission of Children to Employment at Sea (revised 1936). This Convention was adopted by the International LabourConference at its twenty-second session in 1936 and the Frenchand English texts were presented to Parliament in Cmd. 5393. H.M. Government propose to ratify this Convention a year after the date (1st September, 1939) on which the school leaving age is to be raised from 14 to 15 by the provisions of the Educa-tion Act, .1936, and the Education (Scotland) Act, 1936.
